title: Cancer: A Computational Disease that AI Can Cure

And although I've never worked in the Knowledge Systems Lab and Stanford, it's alumni, it's projects.
Technologies and the progeny institutions continue to inspire and inform me to this very day.
I'm going to talk about cancer today from my unique perspective as an AI researcher and Internet entrepreneur and Cancer Survivor.

Unfortunately things are not going very well.
I'm then going to talk about a new paradigm.
Actually a guerrilla war that some of us are trying to wage with the objective of trying to cure cancer one patient at a time.
Which is a lot easier because cancer is just a very heterogeneous disease.
There are probably hundreds if not thousands of variations of cancer.
It's much easier to try to cure one person and generalize from what you've learned.

Long ways towards turning biology into an information science.

In 1998 I was diagnosed with metastatic Melanoma, which is a wicked disease.
Med students learn that in medical school, the one thing to remember about Melanoma is don't get it.
And the median survival is quite quite short.
There were no drugs effective drugs in the pipeline.
The time to develop a new drug is 15 years in a billion dollars.
I didn't have that much time or money and So what to do?
What to do is what every newly diagnosed cancer patient does.

You go running around two different oncologists trying to hear something that you like and what I learned was I went to five different oncologists and got five different opinions and if I listen to any of them I probably would not be here today but I but I actually had a lucky break.
This is when people talk about what goes around comes around.
I was doing some pro bono consulting for Rick Klausner who at the time happened to be running the National Cancer Institute.

And I said Rick, I need some help and he put me in touch with the with the top researchers who were developing Melanoma therapeutics and and these guys had some very very much more interesting offerings.
But none of them could tell me which one was best for me.
And that was the challenge.
That's where the guesswork comes in.

What I wanted, like any good AI researcher would want, is that at each point in my cancer journey, to be able to have all of the world's knowledge and resources together with the decision tools to be able to make the optimal decision.
And then because I'm public minded, I would like to capture the outcomes, good or bad, and at each stage so that they were there to improve the decisions for the next patient coming along.
In the end though, I had to make a gut call and I put my bet my life.
On a clinical trial that failed.
And what's what's interesting about this is the whole notion of clinical trials, which the entire drug industry relies on to develop drugs.

It's where a lot of those 15 years ago.

But the problem with clinical trials in a disease like cancer, which as I said is very heterogeneous, is that when you recruit 100 or 1000 patients for a trial, you're really dealing with the fruit cocktail of diseases and so when a drug you know works on 40% of patients, another drug works on 10% of the patients is the 40% drug better for you?
Well, not necessarily.
It depends whether you're more similar to the 10% of the patients or the 40%.
Another serious problem is that many, many trials fell because they only helped one or two people.
So come on, what disease did we cure that these people have that we've cured?

The BRAF pathway gene at the top of the map kinase pathway is implicated in about 60 or 65% of melanomas, and just recently there's been a drug that's been developed for it.

Breakthrough and leads us to the possibility of trying to treat cancer to win the war on cancer in a different way, which is 1 patient at a time.

So the basic idea is to do what I wanted to do for me to be able to take for each patient, take all of the knowledge and resources in the world, and try to understand what it is that's the best possible treatment for that patient at that moment in time.
Then apply the patient, apply the treatment, and see how the patient does and capture the learnings not just over that patient, but overall patients in order to drive the field forward in general.
So that's the paradigm, and here's basically how it works.

The first is treatment planning for an individual, and there the goal is first of all to find something that will work for that patient to make sure that you get enough shots on goal in the hockey sense, because giving a patient one treatment may disqualify them for a second trial, for example.
So you want to look at all the possibility space for that patient given the best possible shot.
